doc.title: U.S. Equity skewsteep and widespread
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/U.S. Equity skew steep and widespreadU.S. Equity skew steep and widespread_2025-08-28

passages.text: Barclays U.S. Equity Derivatives Strategy provides a weekly monitor, published each Thursday, to help investors track sources of stress and gauge sentiment in the ETF market by leveraging a range of proprietary analytics.

FIGURE 1. HYG vol remains the cheapest among popular hedging options following Jackson Hole; most of the Tsy ETFs populate our cheap volatility screen, in spite of the strong curve steepening; Int'l equities dominate our rich vol screen
US EquityInt'I EquityRatesCreditComdty

FIGURE 2. Volatility stayed firm on most assets with the notable exception of credit, driven by EM credit (EMB), which increases both vs its own history as well as vs longer-dated vol; credit ETFs options activity (normalized by underlying ETF volume) decreased significantly, driven mostly by the increase in HYG volume

ETF Vol/Skew/Vol TS (term- structure)/norm. Ol (open interest) average z- scores = intra asset- class average of z- scores expressed as 1- week MA across US Equity, Int'l Equity, Rates, Credit, and Commodity ETFs. Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.

- Our Bearish Sentiment screen is dominated by US equities, primarily driven by the steep skew / elevated put-to-call open interest ratio (Figure 3); indeed, the 'most expensive' skew screen is entirely dominated by US equities (Figure 4). As recently highlighted (Institutional buyers return), this signals rising demand in downside protection, which is likely to be, among other things, a sign of increasing equities exposure from institutional investors.

- Steep skew makes shallow hedges in the form of put spreads or down-and-out puts more attractive, all else being equal; for instance, for an end-of-the-year hedge, buying SPY Dec25 640/580 put spreads (+/-) (ref., 646.56, 40/15-delta) costs indicatively 1.5%, providing a 6.2-to-1 max expiry payout ratio.
- SHY (1-3y Tsy ETF) tops our Bullish Sentiment screen, as the ETFs saw \(\) 854\(mn in inflows in the past two weeks, a feat that has been surpassed less than 3% of the times in the past 2 years.
FIGURE 3. Top 10 ETFs with Most Bearish/Bullish Sentiment; Bearish, Green = Bullish

The Sentiment Indicator is a weighted average of 2yr %- ile across: 1- week moving average of the Put- to- Call Open Interest Ratio, 2- week change in the 1- week moving average of the Put- to- Call Open Interest Ratio, 1- week moving average of 2m 25- delta skew, 2- week change in skew, 2- week ETF flow, SI and 2- week change in SI (expressed as a %- age of AUM. The weighting scheme is such that the put- to- call open interest, skew, ETF- flow, and SI metrics contribute equally to our Sentiment Indicator Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 4. Top 10 ETFs with expensive skew
FIGURE 5. Top 10 ETFs with cheap skew

Skew: 1- week moving average of the spread between 2m 25- delta put and 2m 25- delta call implied vol, normalized by 2m 50- delta implied vol, i.e., 1w MA 2m (25d put- 25d call)/50d IVOL. This measure of normalized delta skew (as opposed to moneyness skew) allows for easier comparison across ETFs with wildly different base volatility levels.
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.

Skew: 1- week moving average of the spread between 2m 25- delta put and 2m 25- delta call implied vol, normalized by 2m 50- delta implied vol, i.e., 1w MA 2m (25d put- 25d call)/50d IVOL. This measure of normalized delta skew (as opposed to moneyness skew) allows for easier comparison across ETFs with wildly different base volatility levels.
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 6. Top 10 ETFs with expensive down skew
FIGURE 7. Top 10 ETFs with cheap upside skew

Downside skew: 1- week moving average of the spread between 2m 25- delta put and 2m 50- delta implied vol, normalized by 2m 50- delta implied vol, i.e., 1w MA 2m (25d put- 50d)/50d IVOL. This measure of normalized delta skew (as opposed to moneyness skew) allows for easier comparison across ETFs with wildly different base volatility levels
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.

Upside skew: 1- week moving average of the spread between 2m 50- delta and 2m 25- delta call implied vol, normalized by 2m 50- delta implied vol, i.e., 1w MA 2m (50d - 25d call)/50d IVOL. This measure of normalized delta skew (as opposed to moneyness skew) allows for easier comparison across ETFs with wildly different base volatility levels
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 8. Top 10 ETFs with Most/Least options activity

Put + Call Open Interest (and their changes) are normalized by the current ETF volume \*Options Activity Score (%- ile): The average of the 2- yr percentiles of the normalized put+call Ol and the 2- week change thereof Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 9. Equity ETF Valuation

ETFs are ranked based on the equally weighted average of 5yr %- ile of the PE ratio and the ratio of the PE ratio vs. SPX. Past performance is not a guarantee of future results. \*Valuation Score (%- ile): average of the 5- yr percentiles of PE Ratio and its ratio to that of S&P Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.

Top 'bang- for- the- buck' tail hedging screensBelow we screen a universe of 29 cross- asset ETFs with liquid options for the top tail hedges against a number of benchmarks, including Global Equities (MSCI World), Big Tech, EM equities (MSCI EM), Chinese equities (HSCEI), and Commodities (BCOM). In particular, we identify the top 10 drawdowns in any two- month non- overlapping period since 2008 for the benchmark, and ii) calculate and rank based on the average payout (ratio of historical drawdown over current \(\sim 2m\) 25- delta puts). The heat map below shows the highest (green) and lowest (red) put payout ratios at current costs for top 10 drawdowns across the different benchmarks.

FIGURE 10. At current costs, short-dated puts on HYG (US HY Credit), XLF (Fins) and EEM (EM Markets) would have offered the best value for historical 2m drawdowns in global equities (MXwO) US Equity Int'l Equity Credit Comdty

FIGURE 15. Long-term history of cross-asset ETF short-dated implied volatility (z-score)
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26-Aug-25.
FIGURE 16. Long-term history of cross-asset ETF short-dated volatility skew (z-score)

Z- scores are expressed as 1m MA. Skew = 1w MA 2m (25d put - 25d call)/50d IVOL. This measure of normalized delta skew (as opposed to moneyness skew) allows for easier comparison across ETFs with wildly different base volatility levels. Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26-Aug-25.
FIGURE 17. Long-term history of cross-asset ETF volatility term-structure (z-score)
Z- scores are expressed as 1m MA. Volatility Term Structure = ratio of 2m/6m 50d IVOL. Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 18. Long-term history of cross-asset ETF Put + Call OI norm. by ETF volume (z-score)
Z- scores are expressed as 1m MA. Normalized Put + Call OI = # (Put + Call) \*100 / ETF trading volume. Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.
FIGURE 19. History of ETF vol, skew, vol TS, norm. OI z-scores averaged across asset classes

ETF Vol/Skew/Vol TS/norm. OI average z-scores = average of z-score expressed as 1m MA across US Equity, Int' Equity, Rates, Credit, Commodity ETFs. Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26-Aug-25.
FIGURE 20. Long-term history of cross-asset ETF Volatility Risk Premium (VRP)
VRP = 3m MA of ratio of 1m 50-delta implied over subsequent 1m realized volatility  Source: Bloomberg, Data as of 26-Aug-25.
FIGURE 21. Post-Covid 19 shock
FIGURE 22. Current vs historical averages
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg, Data as of 26-Aug-25.
Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg, Data as of 26-Aug-25.
FIGURE 23. Long-term history of inter-sector and cross-asset ETF realized correlation

'Cross- asset' includes: SPY (S&P 500), EFA (EAFE), SHY (1- 3 Yr Treas), IEF (7- 10 Yr Treas), TLT (20+ Yr Treas), LQD (US IG credit), EEM (EM Markets), GLD (Gold), USO (US Oil), SLV (Silver), HYG (US HY credit), EMB (USD EM Bonds). US eq. sector = XLF (Fins), XLK (Tech), XLE (Energy), XLV (Health Care), XLY (Discretionary), XLI (Industrials), XLP (Staples), XLU (Utilities), XLB (Materials), IYR (Real Estate), XHB (Homebuilders), XME (Metals & Mining), XRT (Retail), XLC (Comm Svcs). Source: OptionMetrics, Bloomberg. Data as of 26- Aug- 25.

Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.
